After decades of development, the reaction conditions for direct synthesis of ethylene glycol (EG) from syngas are still very harsh. The pressure required for the reaction is around 435 atm for the state of the art catalyst HRh(CO)3Pi−Pr3. Herein, a new catalyst 1,2-di(phospholan-1-yl)benzene rhodium dicarbonyl hydride is predicted to relieve the harsh reaction conditions by theoretical simulations. In methanol solvent, the highest energy barrier of the new catalyst is 8.7 kcal/mol lower than that of the old catalyst for the rate determining step, which indicates that the bidentate phosphorus ligand effect can significantly improve the catalytic performance compared with traditional monodentate phosphorus ligand catalysts. It is also found that the energy barrier of this reaction is very high in gas phase but it can be significantly decreased under polar solvents, which explains why the current catalysts for the direct synthesis of EG can only be carried out in solution rather than in gas phase. Here, the pressure required for the reaction is promising to be reduced by using the predicted new catalyst, which is improved for direct synthesis of EG. Graphical abstract We found a new catalyst, 1,2-di(phospholan-1-yl)benzene rhodium dicarbonyl hydride, through theoretical prediction for direct synthesis of ethylene glycol from syngas. In the methanol solvent, the highest energy barrier with new catalyst is 8.7 kcal/mol lower than that of old catalyst (HRh(CO)3Pi−Pr3) in the rate determining step. We expect that the temperature and pressure required for the reaction can be significantly reduced by using this catalyst. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Synthesis of ethylene glycol Bidentate phosphorus ligand Rhodium catalyst Abbreviations FAL formaldehyde GAL glycolaldehyde EG ethylene glycol PES potential energy surface 1 Introduction Ethylene glycol (EG) is a chemical that widely used in many commercial and industrial applications, including automobile antifreeze and coolant. It is also used as a raw material for the production of a variety of products, such as polyester resins, fibers, plasticizers and surfactants. [1] The global EG capacity increased from 30 million metric tons in 2014 to 42 million metric tons in 2019. And it is expected to increase to 65 million metric tons in 2024. [2] In industry, EG is mainly produced from ethylene in petroleum, via the reaction intermediate ethylene oxide. [1,3] Due to the diminishing petroleum resources, the production of EG from coal via syngas has become another important research topic. Synthesis of EG from syngas can be divided into direct and indirect methods. The indirect method involved with multi-steps/catalysts has been commercialized recently. [1,4,5] However, more and more effects have been focusing on the direct synthesis of EG from syngas as it is an atomic economic reaction. In 1948, DuPont's patent report showed that Co2(CO)8 catalyst converted syngas to ethylene glycol, methanol and other alcohols under a pressure of 304 Mpa. [6] However, the harsh reaction conditions and low ethylene glycol yield could not satisfy the requirements of industrial production. In the 1970s, UCC first reported rhodium carbonyl complex as catalyst in the direct method, [7] but there are still some problems such as unstable performance, low catalytic activity, high reaction pressure and low selectivity. In 1986, Sumitomo Chemical Co. studied different alkyl phosphorus ligands of the rhodium carbonyl catalyst, [8] and found that the yield of EG and methanol was affected by the replacement of alkyl phosphorus ligands. Among the studied alkyl phosphorus ligands, P-i-Pr3 showed the highest activity, while P-t-Bu3 gave the best selectivity. But the developed catalysts still could not achieve the order of magnitude change. By using this type of catalyst (triisopropylphosphine rhodium tricarbonyl hydride, HRh(CO)3Pi−Pr3), at 220 °C and under 44 MPa, turn-over frequencies for ethylene glycol and methanol were 6.2 and 4.3, respectively. Some ruthenium catalysts have also been developed. [9,10] But these catalysts also have the same problems, such as harsh reaction conditions and easy decomposition of catalysts. However, no matter using different alkyl phosphorus ligands or addition of promoters, even changing the solvent, the reactivity of this reaction is still very low, indicating that the key problem should be the catalyst itself. In addition, the reaction needs to be carried out at high temperature and high pressure while the thermodynamic data show that it is unfavorable for the reaction at high temperature, [12,38] which means that the energy barrier is too high and it is necessary to raise the temperature to overcome the energy barrier. The high temperature further leads to the reaction must be carried out under high pressure. These problems make this direct method almost no progress for decades. At present, this experiment must be carried out under extremely high pressure, the extreme harsh reaction conditions limit the progress of the experiment. In order to solve this problem fundamentally, it is necessary to find a new strategy to design catalysts. However, it is a feasible way to predict the catalyst with reduced reaction energy barrier by theoretical calculations. Therefore, we screened some new rhodium-based catalysts with different ligands through theoretical simulations. The results indicate that a new catalyst 1,2-di(phospholan-1-yl)benzene rhodium dicarbonyl hydride with bidentate phosphorus ligand can reduce the energy barrier compared with traditional monodentate phosphorus ligand catalysts, which may relieve the harsh reaction conditions for direct synthesis of EG. 2 Computational methods In experiments, the reaction for direct method is carried out in solution. Although the solvent effect can be simulated by the polarizable continuum model (PCM), [13–15] the strong force between solvent and solute molecules cannot be treated by PCM, such as hydrogen bond. In addition, many promoters are used in the experiments, which makes the whole reaction very complicated. Therefore, in order to clearly understand the influence of catalyst characteristics on the energy barrier, the reaction potential energy surfaces (PES) of different catalysts in the gas phase were calculated first to screen the catalysts, and then PCM were applied to consider the solvent effect for the catalysts with best performance. The gas-phase geometric structure of a molecular species were calculated with a density-functional method ωB97X-D [16] and a basis set def2-TZVP [17,18]. The vibrational frequencies and thermal correction to Gibbs free energy of a molecular species were calculated at optimized geometry using the same level of theory. All the energies listed in this study are Gibbs free energies. The connection of a transition state structure with its reactant and product was confirmed by intrinsic reaction coordinate [19] (IRC) calculation. In order to get more accurate energy, single-point energy calculation of the optimized molecular species was performed with a double-hybrid density functional PWPB95-D3 [20] (with the inclusion of Grimme's D3 dispersion correction [21]) and a basis set def2-QZVPP [17,18]. Solution-phase structures are optimized at M06–2X/6–31G* (SDD for Rh) level of theory [22–24] with the inclusion of Grimme's D3 dispersion correction using Truhlar's SMD implicit solvation model [25]. The vibrational frequencies and Gibbs free energy were also calculated at the same level of theory. The electronic energy in solution (Esol) and thermal correction to Gibbs Free Energy(Gsol) were got in this calculation. In order to include the solvation free energy, the solution-phase optimized geometries were subjected to single-point calculations at the same level of theory at gas-phase. The electronic energy in gas-phase (Egas) was obtained in this calculation. High level single-point electronic energy calculation of the optimized molecular species was calculated at gas-phase, and also performed with PWPB95-D3/def2-QZVPP level of theory. The high accuracy single-point electronic energy in gas-phase (Eele) was obtained in this calculation. Total energy in solution phase is Eele + Gsol + (Esol - Egas). Finally, a standard state correction of 1.89 kcal/mol is applied to account for conversion of the gas-phase standard state 1 atm to a solution-phase concentration of 1 M at 298.15 K. [26] The functional ωB97X-D, M06–2X calculations were performed using the Gaussian 09 program [27], and the functional PWPB95-D3 calculations were performed using the Orca 4.0 program [28,29]. Atomic partial charges were calculated using natural population analysis (NPA) in the Gaussian 09 program. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The PES of the HRh(CO)3Pi−Pr3 catalyzed formation of FAL The reactants of the direct synthesis of ethylene glycol are three H2 molecules and two CO molecules, which are carried out through several reaction steps. Formaldehyde (FAL) and glycolaldehyde (GAL) are considered to be important intermediates of this reaction. [9,30] Therefore, the complete reaction can be considered as a three-stage process, as shown below: (1) H2 + CO → H2CO (FAL) (2) H2CO + H2 + CO → H2COHCHO (GAL) (3) H2COHCHO + H2 → (H2COH)2 (ethylene glycol) Pidun et al. have calculated the reaction mechanism of the HRh(CO)4 catalyzed hydrogenation of carbon monoxide, [31] that is, the steps of FAL formation in the above equation. But the complete reaction mechanism has not been calculated. The complicated reaction mechanism increases the difficulty of theoretical calculations. It would be a huge and difficult work to find a new catalyst by calculating a complete reaction pathway. However, Ishino et al. studied the reaction mechanism of direct synthesis of EG in experiments. [32] The experimental results show that the rate determining step in this reaction is the formation of FAL from H2 + CO, and FAL is also an important intermediate in this reaction. In this study, FAL was directly added to the reaction solution, and they observed that the yield of EG was proportional to the amount of FAL added. In addition, there are many published studies on the synthesis of EG using FAL as raw material. [4,33,34] These information indicate that the key step in the direct synthesis of EG is the formation of FAL from H2 + CO, and the high energy barrier in this step is the fundamental problem. Therefore, we will try to replace the different ligands on the rhodium catalyst to find the best candidate that can reduce the barrier of H2 + CO → H2CO reaction in our calculation. The effect of monodentate phosphorus ligands on rhodium catalysts has been studied by the experiments of Tamura et al. [8] The results show that the best ligand is triisopropylphosphine (P-i-Pr3). As mentioned above, the HRh(CO)3Pi−Pr3 catalyst is a relatively better catalyst for direct synthesis of EG. [8] Therefore, we will first study the reaction path of HRh(CO)3Pi−Pr3 catalyst and compare it with the new catalyst. Then, the effect of bidentate ligands, including some non-phosphorus ligands will be investigated. After finding the best catalyst, we will calculate the full reaction path of the 3 H2 + 2 CO → ethylene glycol of both catalysts, in order to confirm the complete reaction mechanism of this reaction and compare the new catalyst with the old one (HRh(CO)3Pi−Pr3). Fig. 1 shows the optimized geometries of the energy-minimum conformation of the HRh(CO)3Pi−Pr3 catalyst. This catalyst has two stable isomers. The most stable structure is hydrogen in the trans position of the phosphorus ligand (Fig. 1a), and the hydrogen of the other isomer is in the cis position of the phosphorus ligand as shown in Fig. 1b. Its energy is about 0.4 kcal/mol higher than the trans-isomer at PWPB95-D3/def2-QZVPP//ωB97X-D/def2-TZVP level of theory. Fig. 2 shows the PES of the HRh(CO)3Pi−Pr3 catalyzed formation of FAL from H2 + CO. "TS" indicate that is a transition state, and "I" represent an intermediate. Two HRh(CO)3Pi−Pr3 isomers are expressed as I1a and I1b. Trans-isomer(I1a) and cis-isomer(I1b) are converted via TS1, and the energy barrier is 10.8 kcal/mol. The formation of FAL from H2 + CO is completed through three step reactions. The first step is the hydrogen transfer to one of the CO and form HCO (I1b→I2). According to the IRC result, the reaction in this step will only be carried out by cis-isomer. The energy of the TS2 and I2 are very close indicates that I2 is not a stable intermediate. The addition of H2 to the intermediate I2 leads to the dihydrogen intermediate I3. The third step is to transfer one of the hydrogen on the rhodium to the carbon of HCO to form FAL (I3→I4). The transition state (TS3) energy of this step is 39.3 kcal/mol, which is also the step with the highest transition state energy at this stage. CO can be easily added to the unsaturated rhodium center without energy barrier, and the intermediate I4 becomes the original catalyst HRh(CO)3Pi−Pr3 when CO is added. Similarly, the intermediate I2 will become I5 when CO is added, but the subsequent reaction of I5 must go through a H2 addition reaction with extremely high barrier (TS6). I1a can also become intermediate I5 through the direct insertion of CO. However, the energy barrier of this step is also very high (TS5). Therefore, I5, TS5 and TS6 are not important at this stage, and the highest energy barrier is 39.3 kcal/mol for the formation of FAL from H2 + CO. According to the study of Ishino et al. [32], this stage is the rate determination step of direct synthesis of ethylene glycol. Therefore, by studying this stage and comparing the highest reaction energy barriers of different catalysts, we can find the most suitable candidate for direct synthesis of ethylene glycol. 3.2 The PES of new catalysts for formation of FAL The effect of monodentate phosphorus ligands on rhodium catalysts has been studied by the experiments of Tamura et al.. According to our preliminary calculations, other non-phosphorus monodentate ligands are very easy to combine with the hydrogen on rhodium and dissociate from the rhodium atom. Therefore, we focus on bidentate ligands. Considering some factors and ligand design rules, [35,36] such as the steric effects of ligands and the difficulty of experimental synthesis, we selected some ligands for screening as follows: 1,5-cyclooctadiene (labelled as L1), 1,10-phenanthroline (labelled as L2), 2,9-dimethyl-1,10-phenanthroline (labelled as L3), 2,9-dichloro-1,10-phenanthroline (labelled as L4), 2,2′-bipyridine (labelled as L5), hosphinino [3,2-h]phosphinoline (labelled as L6), 1,2-di(phospholan-1-yl)benzene (labelled as L7), 1,2-bis(2,5-dimethylphospholan-1-yl)benzene (labelled as L8). The calculation results show that L1-L5 will be easily replaced by CO, which highlights that only phosphorus ligands have high stability. We found that the bridge connecting the two phosphorus must be a rigid structure, such as benzene, naphthalene and phenanthrene. If the skeleton uses a structure with low hardness to connect the two phosphorus, the two phosphorusare can easily turn into a non coplanar structure, and at this time, CO is easy to replace the phosphorus. For example, our preliminary study (ωB97X-D/def2-SVP method is used) shows that if we replace the benzene ring in L7 with C = C double bond or CC single bond, the relative energy of HRh(CO)3 Ln to HRh(CO)2 Ln + CO will be reduced from 17.2 kcal/mol of L7 to 11.9 and 10.1 kcal/mol for the ligand that the benzene ring replaced by C = C double bond and CC single bond, respectively. The comparison of L2 and L5 from Table 1 also shows the same conclusion; Replacing phenanthrene in L2 ligand with biphenyl will reduced the relative energy of HRh(CO)3 Ln to HRh(CO)2 Ln + CO from 3.4 kcal/mol to 2.2 kcal/mol, and the catalyst is easier to be replaced by CO. The length of the rigid plane structure will also directly affect the distance between the phosphorus atom and Rh, and is also related to the stability of the catalyst. Therefore, we choose the benzene ring as the skeleton of the rigid structure. We also found that it is necessary to add appropriate substituents to ligands to increase steric hindrance, which makes it more difficult for ligands to be replaced by CO and increases the stability of the catalyst. We found that if the substituent is too small, CO can easily insert and replace phosphorus ligands. For example, the comparison of L2 and L3 shows that the increased methyl group can make the ligand more difficult to be replaced by CO. However, if the substituent is too large, it will increase the barrier of H2 addition. An obvious example is that the energy barrier of L8 is higher than that of L7. For the selection of phosphorus ligands, especially L7 and L8, we also refer to an another very important factor, that is, we choose the ligands that have been stably synthesized. The CAS number of L7 is 175,845–24–6, and the CAS number of L8 is 147,253–67–6. Therefore, we choose the most potential catalyst among the ligands that have been synthesized. The catalysts with these ligands (HRh(CO)2 Ln(n = 1–8)) have been studied by calculating the PES of H2 + CO → H2CO reaction. The structures of catalysts with these ligands are show in the Fig. 3 . In order to show the structure more clearly, some hydrogen atoms in HRhCO2 L7 and HRh(CO)2 L8 are not shown. The experiment is carried out in the presence of a lot of CO. So, CO is one of the reactants and is also a ligand that can coordinate on rhodium atom and may replace other ligands. In the preliminary calculations, we also found that some ligands are easily replaced by CO. Therefore, the relative energies of the catalyst molecule with one more CO added (HRh(CO)3 Ln) were also considered. The highest energy barrier of these catalysts in H2 + CO → H2CO reaction and the energy of HRh(CO)3 Ln relative to the original catalyst HRh(CO)2 Ln + CO are listed in Table 1. The ligand triisopropylphosphine (expressed as L0) is also listed in Table 1 for comparison. For the relative energy of HRh(CO)3 Ln to HRh(CO)2 Ln + CO, the higher the relative energy of HRh(CO)3 Ln, the lower the chance of its substitution by CO, and the stronger its binding ability to rhodium. The relative energies of HRh(CO)3 L to HRh(CO)2 L + CO show that the coordination ability of phosphorus ligand with rhodium was higher than that of nitrogen ligand, while the charge of rhodium atom coordinated by phosphorus ligand was also more negative, that is, electron density at the metal center is enhanced. The charges of natural population analysis (or commonly called NBO charges) of Rh atoms are also listed in Table 1. The three catalysts with phosphorus ligands show that the more negative the charge of rhodium atom, the lower the energy barrier at this stage. For all ligands, the step with highest energy barrier is the transfer of H to HCO to form FAL, which is the same as the reaction path in Fig. 2. The results show that 1,2-di(phospholan-1-yl)benzene (L7) is the best ligand for reducing the energy barrier of this reaction. Fig. 4 shows the optimized geometries of the energy-minimum conformation of the 1,2-di(phospholan-1-yl)benzene rhodium dicarbonyl hydride catalyst (expressed as HRh(CO)2 L7). This catalyst can also be expressed as two isomers, that is, hydrogen in the trans position (Fig. 4a) of the phosphorus and hydrogen in the cis position (Fig. 4b) of the phosphorus. The energy difference between the two isomers is 4.5 kcal/mol at PWPB95-D3/def2-QZVPP//ωB97X-D/def2-TZVP level of theory. Two isomers are converted via a transition state with the energy barrier of 9.2 kcal/mol. 3.3 The full PES of the new and the old catalysts In order to investigate the difference between the new catalyst (HRh(CO)2 L7) and the old catalyst (HRh(CO)3Pi−Pr3, also expressed as HRh(CO)3 L0) in detail for formation of ethylene glycol, we calculated the full PES for the two catalysts. The full PES is calculated via three piecewise stages. The first is the reaction of H2 + CO to form FAL, and the second stage is the hydroformylation of FAL to form glycolaldehyde (GAL), the final stage is the hydrogenation of glycolaldehyde to form EG. Fig. 5 and Fig. 6 shows the full PES of the formation of EG catalyzed by the HRh(CO)3 L0 and HRh(CO)2 L7, respectively. There are three H2 and two CO in this reaction. Based on different addition sequences, there may be many different reaction mechanisms. In the stage of formaldehyde formation, there is no sequential problem in the addition of H2 and CO. However, in the reaction stages after formaldehyde, we will encounter the problem of adding H2 or CO first. Therefore, we have considered this in detail when calculating the reaction mechanism. In our calculation, different reaction paths are considered at the same time, and the path with higher energy barrier is omitted. The structures of the intermediates and transition states are listed in the Supplementary Material. In Fig. 5a and Fig. 6a, the reaction to form FAL has been described above. The highest energy barrier is the step of transferring hydrogen to HCO. In this stage, the highest energy barrier of the new catalyst is 7.1 kcal/mol lower than that of the old catalyst. In Fig. 5 and Fig. 6, it can be seen that the transition state of hydrogen transfer has the highest energy barrier for both catalysts at each stage. The hydroformylation of FAL in the second stage (Fig. 5b and 6b) are unexpected. For the HRh(CO)3 L0 catalyst, the highest energy barrier of GAL formation path is 57.8 kcal/mol, while the highest energy barrier of GAL formation path is 48.2 kcal/mol for the HRh(CO)2 L7 catalyst. Both of them are about 16.0∼19.0 kcal/mol higher than that of the first stage. However, according to the experimental results of Ishino et al., the rate determining step of the formation of EG should be the first stage, that is, the stage for the formation of FAL. So, this calculation result is inconsistent with the experiment. The same problem also appeared in the stage of hydrogenation of glycolaldehyde. For both catalysts, the highest energy barrier in the third stage is about 12.0 kcal/mol higher than that in the first stage. The highest energy barriers of HRh(CO)3 L0 and HRh(CO)2 L7 are 50.8 and 44.6 kcal/mol, respectively. This result is not as expectation, and the most significant difference between the experiment and the calculation is that the experiment is carried out in a solvent environment. Therefore, in the next section we will calculate the solvent effect to discuss this issue. Another important by-product methanol was also formed in the second stage, and the highest energy barrier for methanol formation path of both catalysts are slightly lower than those of the glycolaldehyde formation path. In experiments, the selectivity of methanol and ethylene glycol is also an important issue, and many promoters were used to improve the selectivity. As the reaction mechanism would become rather complicated when the promoters are added, we will not discuss this issue in this work. 3.4 Solvent effect In order to clarify the solvent effect on the reaction, we calculated the complete PES under the solvation model for both catalysts. In the previous experiments, 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) was found to be a better solvent for this reaction, but NMP was not defined in the SMD solvation model of the Gaussian program, and some parameters for custom define this solvent were also not available. However, the dielectric constant of NMP is 32.3 [37], which is similar to that of methanol. NMP and methanol are both highly polar solvents. For comparison, another solvent of low polarity was also chosen for simulation. Thus, methanol with high polarity and benzene without polarity were chosen to investigate the solvent effect. The dielectric constants of methanol and benzene in the Gaussian program are 32.613 and 2.2706, respectively. Base on our preliminary calculations, we found that some structures in the solution phase are significantly different from those in the gas phase. So, the structures we used to simulate solvent effect were optimized in the solution phase. Table 2 lists the highest energy barriers in the solution phase and gas phase of each stage. The highest energy barriers for the formation of methanol are also listed in this table for comparison. The complete reaction PES for the solution phase is listed in the Supplementary Material. In the first stage, the solvent has only a small effect on the HRh(CO)3 L0 catalyst, but a significant effect on the HRh(CO)2 L7 catalyst. Especially in methanol solvent, the highest energy barrier is reduced by 6.5 kcal/mol compared with that in the gas phase. In the second stage, the effect of solvent is extremely obvious, especially in methanol solvent. The highest energy barrier of both catalysts is lower than that in the gas phase by about 25.0 kcal/mol. No matter in methanol or benzene solvent, the highest energy barrier of the third stage catalyzed by both catalysts is also decreased significantly. The highest energy barriers are lower than those of the first and second stages. In the gas phase, the highest energy barrier of the second and third stages of this reaction is very high, but it is obviously reduced in methanol solvent, which can also explain why the current study on the direct synthesis of EG is carried out in the solution phase. For all stages, including the formation of methanol, the effect of methanol solvent is more obvious than that of benzene solvent. This means that polar solvent is better than non-polar solvent for this reaction. Previous experiments have shown that the rate determining step of direct synthesis of ethylene glycol is in the first stage. In the methanol solvent, the highest energy barrier of HRh(CO)3 L0 and HRh(CO)2 L7 catalyzed reaction in the second stage are lower than that in the first stage, which is in agreement with the experimental results. There are two main reasons for the obvious reduction of the reaction energy barrier in the second and third stages. First, the solvent effect changes the reaction path. For example, the potential energy surface of HRh(CO)2 L7 is obviously different in gas phase (Fig. 6) and methanol solvent (Fig. S9). In the gas phase, the highest reaction energy barrier (TS9) (Fig. S5) of this stage will be divided into two steps in methanol solvent, namely TS9–1 and TS9–2 (Fig. S12), which will also significantly reduce the energy barrier. In this system, this phenomenon can also be seen in Fig. 2. The energy of TS5 in Fig. 2 is much higher than that of TS1 and TS2. Second, this is a reaction with reduced molecular number. The solvent helps to reduce the Gibbs free energy of formation of the reaction. The standard Gibbs free energy of formation of EG in the gas phase is −4.6 kcal/mol, while that in methanol and benzene solvents are −36.1 and −23.2 kcal/mol respectively, at the same level of theory. Therefore, we can see that in the second and third stages, the energy of whole potential energy surface in the solvent is significantly lower than that in the gas phase, including transition states and intermediates. In addition, the products and intermediates of this reaction are polar molecules, so polar solvents also help to reduce the energy of these molecules. According to our calculation results, we can see the significant difference between benzene and methanol solvents, indicating that the polarity of the solvent is very important. The solvent also has some influences on the selectivity of methanol and GAL. For example, in methanol solvent, the highest energy barrier of GAL formation path is 21.7 kcal/mol with HRh(CO)2 L7 catalyst, while the energy barrier of methanol formation path is 34.2 kcal/mol. So, the reaction tends obviously to form GAL in methanol solvent. However, in benzene solvent, the highest energy barrier of the reaction path for the formation of GAL is very close to that for the formation of methanol, and the selectivity for the formation of GAL and methanol will also be very close for benzene solvent. Therefore, use different solvents to change the selectivity of products will be a valuable research topic in the future. 3.5 Temperature and pressure required for the reaction The simulation of solvation model is consistent with the experiments, that is, the reaction must be carried out in polar solvent, such as methanol or NMP. So, we will also estimate the temperature and pressure required for the reaction in methanol solvent based on this condition. The Gibbs free energy of formation of FAL, GAL and EG in the methanol at several temperatures and pressures are listed in Table 3 . Thermodynamic analyses show the standard Gibbs free energy of formation of FAL, GAL and EG are 3.1, −24.3, and −36.1 kcal/mol, respectively. However, the rate constant of HRh(CO)3Pi−Pr3 catalyzed reaction will be 3 × 10−13 s − 1 at normal temperature and pressure based on the Transition State Theory (TST) with the barrier of 34.4 kcal/mol, which indicates that the reaction is almost impossible to happen. Therefore, it is necessary to raise the temperature to increase the rate constant, and hence the experiment was carried out at 220 °C. However, Table 3 also shows that it is unfavorable for the reaction at high temperature, the Gibbs free energy of formation of FAL is 2.3 kcal/mol at 220 °C and 1 atm, and the reaction will not proceed. Therefore, the experiment was carried out under 435 atm. At 220 °C and under 435 atm, the energy barrier of HRh(CO)3Pi−Pr3 catalyzed reaction changes slightly from 34.4 kcal/mol to 35.1 kcal/mol, and the estimated rate constant is increased to 3.0 × 10−3 s − 1, the Gibbs free energy of formation of FAL is −3.6 kcal/mol. In order to estimate the reaction conditions of the new catalyst HRh(CO)2 L7, we will use this rate constant and Gibbs free energy of formation of FAL as a standard reference. The rate constant is a function of reaction energy barrier and temperature, Gibbs free energy of formation changes with temperature and pressure, and the reaction energy barrier also changes slightly with temperature and pressure. Considering the interaction of these variables, we calculated that the reaction barrier of the new HRh(CO)2 L7 catalyzed reaction at 90 °C and 25 atm is 25.6 kcal/mol. At this condition, the rate constant is 3 × 10−3 s −1, and the Gibbs free energy of formation of FAL is −3.6 kcal/mol, which is the same with the old catalyst at 220 °C and 435atm. Fig. 7 shows the relationship between temperature and pressure when the Gibbs free energy of formation of FAL is −3.6 kcal/mol in the methanol solvent. We also use the same method to estimate the temperature and pressure required by the new catalyst in the second and third stages of the reaction. The results show that the temperature and pressure required in the second or third stage are much lower than those in the first stage. Therefore, we expect that the HRh(CO)2 L7 catalyst could carry out the reaction at a lower temperature (90 °C), and the pressure required for the reaction would also be lower significantly (25 atm). 4 Conclusions We have found a new 1,2-di(phospholan-1-yl)benzene rhodium dicarbonyl hydride (HRh(CO)2 L7) catalyst through theoretical prediction, which can significantly reduce the energy barrier of the direct synthesis of EG. According to the prediction of SMD solvation model, in polar solvents such as methanol, the energy barrier of this reaction will be significantly lower than that in non-polar solvents and gas phase. In the methanol solvent, the highest energy barrier of HRh(CO)2 L7 catalyzed reaction is 8.7 kcal/mol lower than that of old HRh(CO)3Pi−Pr3 catalyzed reaction in the rate determining step. So, we expect that the temperature needed for this reaction can be significantly reduced to 90 °C by the estimation of basic Transition State Theory. According to the thermodynamic analyses, the lower the temperature is conducive to the reduction of the pressure required by this reaction. According to our prediction, the pressure required for the reaction is expected to decrease significantly, but because the reactants are gas, the pressure will affect the solubility of the reactant gas, and the solubility is related to the concentration of the reactant. Therefore, the decrease of pressure will be accompanied by the decrease of reactant concentration, and the reaction rate will also decrease under the same reaction rate constant. The change of solubility and reactant concentration caused by pressure change cannot be predicted simply by theoretical calculation, which will indeed lead to the error between calculation and experiment, resulting in the inaccuracy of our prediction of new reaction temperature and pressure. However, what we changed in this study is the ligand of the catalyst. In the reaction mechanism, the ligand did not bond directly with H2 or CO, and the ligand mainly changed the charge and properties of Rh atom. Therefore, we believe that the errors for HRh(CO)3Pi−Pr3 and HRh(CO)2 L7 are close, that is, this error is not affected by the change of ligand. We believe that the superiority of HRh(CO)2 L7 can be confirmed through the comparison between HRh(CO)2 L7 and HRh(CO)3Pi−Pr3. However, whether the reaction pressure can be greatly reduced to 25 atm as we predicted needs experimental verification. coredata.dc:description: After decades of development, the reaction conditions for direct synthesis of ethylene glycol (EG) from syngas are still very harsh. The pressure required for the reaction is around 435 atm for the state of the art catalyst HRh(CO)3Pi−Pr3. Herein, a new catalyst 1,2-di(phospholan-1-yl)benzene rhodium dicarbonyl hydride is predicted to relieve the harsh reaction conditions by theoretical simulations. In methanol solvent, the highest energy barrier of the new catalyst is 8.7 kcal/mol lower than that of the old catalyst for the rate determining step, which indicates that the bidentate phosphorus ligand effect can significantly improve the catalytic performance compared with traditional monodentate phosphorus ligand catalysts. It is also found that the energy barrier of this reaction is very high in gas phase but it can be significantly decreased under polar solvents, which explains why the current catalysts for the direct synthesis of EG can only be carried out in solution rather than in gas phase. Here, the pressure required for the reaction is promising to be reduced by using the predicted new catalyst, which is improved for direct synthesis of EG.
coredata.dc:title: Rhodium-based bidentate phosphorus ligand catalyst for direct synthesis of ethylene glycol
